urn:contentItem:5J2R-B461-DY0W-422V-00000-00Refusing to Call Illegal 'Illegal'; Exec's Questionable Death; Bank Fine Blowback2014-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:26ZLexisNexisRefusing to Call Illegal 'Illegal'; Exec's Questionable Death; Bank Fine BlowbackLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: Good evening, everyone, and welcome. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And here's why the president believes it's no big deal not visiting the border. Who in the media is really going to call him on it? Think about it.

I've looked into this, my friends, and here is what I discovered. This illegal immigration crisis, well, it's not even a crisis. It's not inhumane. The way we are treating these tens of thousands of illegals dumped on us is what's inhumane. Not illegal, inhumane.

In fact, to the mainstream media, it's not even about illegals at all. They won't even use the term "illegal."

Now, more on that in a second. For now, I want you to concentrate on how they're covering this story - not what they are including, what they are omitting. It is the way they frame this argument. It is the way they discuss this issue by never using the word "illegal."

Well, they rid themselves of the nuisance of having to explain all of these thousands of people who are breaking the law, our laws, our country. No, no. You see, they're not the problem. We are! And Republicans, well, they're even worse. They're not patriots, they're bigots. They're not against illegal immigration, now, they're just against all immigration. It's morphed into that.

Get ready for this, because what I'm about to show you proves it. These are unedited, undoctored, very real clips, headlines, stories from a sampling of news items on the ongoing illegal immigration mess that never use the word "illegal" once. Not once.

The Washington Post, June 30th: "It's OK that Congress won't act on immigration."

The L.A. Times, July 5th: "A mounting backlog of immigration courts..."

BusinessWeek, this week: "With immigration reform dead on Capitol Hill, President Obama says he will use his executive authority to make changes to the law himself."

NBC News' Matt Lauer urging viewers to share their thoughts on Twitter by calling these latest immigrants - not illegal immigrants - immigrants by #RefugeeRiders and they are never to be called "illegal" at all. NBC choosing instead the term "undocumented". Ditto CBS.

In fact, the L.A. Times and the Associated Press have announced a ban on the term "illegal immigrants." They say it broadly and unfairly labels a large group of people.

Well, that makes things easy, doesn't it? Sort of like dispensing with the term "global warming" after a few harsh winters then ta da! It's climate change. Who can argue with that?

So now by saying we have an immigration crisis, you could say that anyone who's against these waves of illegals coming here are anti-immigrant or worse, anti- I don't know - human being. Suddenly, they're not for illegal immigration reform, they're against immigration reform. Immigration reform.

Leave out the illegal part and you might almost forget the billions we are spending on processing these tens of thousands of illegal kids dumped in this country into thinking that they are citizens of this country. They are not. And those opposed to keeping these noncitizens here are racist. They are not.

You see, when you leave out words you don't like, you can kind of say anything you do like. But let me tell you something. I can call myself "calorically-challenged" instead of "fat" to make myself feel good but that doesn't make me any less fat. So fat chance it'll make me anymore aware.

But those are my thoughts. I'd love to hear yours. Use #Cavuto and I'll share them with the world.

First to Accuracy in Media Editor, Roger Aronoff.

Roger, this started as a curious little project on my part - just seeing what I could get just hearing and reading media stories - and it's true. "Illegal" doesn't happen. It's a word you can't find. What happened?

ROGER ARONOFF, ACCURACY IN MEDIA EDITOR: Oh, you're exactly right, Neil. Great to be with you today and it was a great setup. Yes. For instance, the Associated Press took it out of their style book so that you can no longer say "illegal aliens" because it's too judgmental and it might hurt someone's feelings so they've just removed it from the lexicon. It's only used to describe actions and not people. And that just serves--.

CAVUTO: But they will freely write stories of - those critical of what we're doing right now at the border - they can still be called "bigots". They can still be called "obstructionists" or God knows what. But "illegal" somehow is now taken on a bad connotation and who are we afraid of offending again?

ARONOFF: Well, that's right. What's going on here, I believe, is that there's an agenda. They are pushing for this so-called comprehensive immigration reform also known as amnesty and they also want to protect President Obama. They have a lot invested in him. So this is what they're doing. I mean, we're looking at this 50,000 children that have come over but there's really even a much larger story. There was a piece in the New York Times last week and this is the New York Times that acknowledged that since April alone, there have been 240,000 adult migrants - they call them - that have come across as well and most of them are just released to go where they want to in the U.S.

CAVUTO: And back and forth and back and forth. The recidivism is beyond the pale. But here's what is amazing to me. When you ignore the obvious and you've written about this brilliantly, then you don't do what should be obvious. When you talk about the rights of illegals or illegals have to be given a license to drive and illegals - in some communities - they even have to be given the right to vote. In New York City, they're debating that as we speak and I'm thinking to myself, "What part of 'illegal' do they not understand?" What part of 'noncitizen' do they not understand? What part of stealing their way across the border for whatever reason do they not understand? And then I'm thinking of all the well-intended immigrants who are coming here and going through the process, who also write me and say, "What the heck?"

ARONOFF: You're absolutely right. I mean, this is the worst it's for the legal aliens - the people who do the right thing and get in line and come here - and this flood of illegal immigrants has created massive headaches for them and for many of us who are really very pro-immigrant but anti- illegal immigrant, it's - this is a disaster and it's really a manufactured crisis. You look back at a couple of things. Obama's trying to blame this back on this 2008 law that really, there was the 2012 DACA - Deferred Action for Childhood Admissions - and the other thing is that we know there was a contract put out in January of this year that specified 65,00 children coming here calling for escorts to bring them here. So they have known this exactly and this is really a manufactured crisis and now, even this week, we've seen this other kind of maneuver where first they put out that it was going to be 1.8 billion, and then all of a sudden, no, it's 3.7 billion. They've tried to find--.

CAVUTO: Oh, it'll go steadily higher than that, Roger, But your points are all well taken as usual. Thank you very, very much.

Oh, by the way, I was thinking of Nancy Pelosi also changing the fact it's not a border issue, that this is an Americas issue - North America, Central America, South America. We're all one. Who knew? I had to go back and look at my (INAUDIBLE) now.

All right. To former Florida Republican Congressman Allen West who's seen and heard enough.

What do you think of this, Congressman? Illegal, no more, don't use it?

FMR. REP. ALLEN WEST, (R) FLORIDA: Well, Neil, you hit the nail on the head when you start looking at how liberal progressives changed the lexicon. They are not "illegal immigrants". They're "undocumented workers." You don't have "drug dealers", you have "unlicensed pharmacists". You don't even have "combat operations", you have "overseas contingency operations." You have "man-caused disasters" instead of "terrorist attacks". And in recently, just out in California, we don't have "husband and wife" anymore, we have "spouse one and spouse two".

CAVUTO: You're right.

WEST: So you're right. As you change the language, then you make the thing that is obvious and the problem that should be dealt with completely un-dealable. You can't deal with it anymore because then--.

CAVUTO: Well, that's just it. If you don't even define the problem, you can't address the problem. If you don't see the problem and just call it like something else and equate the same rights and standards to people who shouldn't be here that you do the people who already are here, the people who already are here get a little annoyed and the people who want to legally get here and go through the process of becoming permanent citizens here - they get annoyed too.

WEST: Well, they get discouraged. I mean, look at what is happening as far as the release of those five senior members of the Taliban. Everyone is calling them "prisoners of war". That's not what they are. They are "unlawful enemy combatants" and they don't deserve any rights. And these non-state, non-uniform belligerents that are captured on this modern battlefield basically not represented or not recognized by the Geneva Convention, but yet, what do we continue to do just like this gentlemen Khatallah that we brought back from Libya, we get them constitutional rights, we get them lawyered up. So--.

CAVUTO: I think we're way too politically correct (INAUDIBLE), not even your camp or Sarah Palin's camp that we should start filing impeachment charges against the president. I understand your frustration though. But I - what I'm saying is we are so super careful - go ahead.

WEST: My frustration - my frustration is very narrowly defined with the president because I see a national security threat and that's why I see high crimes and misdemeanors. When the President of the United States of America makes a unilateral decision to release five senior members of the enemy while the enemy is still engaged in combat operations against us, that's providing material, comfort, and aid to an enemy. That's aiding and abetting your enemy.

CAVUTO: Well, no, no. I see your point there. I'll respectfully disagree with you. I can do so because you're in remote. If we were here in person, you'd hit me so I feel safe in doing this right now. But Allen, I will say this and I've already pushed time here but I am overly concerned about this incredible political incorrect environment in which we live and now how the media's signing onto it with one of the biggest crisis we face - that is our problem at the border - because you have a complicit media saying, "What problem at the border?"

WEST: Yes. You're absolutely right and you have a Nancy Pelosi who says it's not a crisis, this is an opportunity. You have Valerie Jarrett who is changed the--

CAVUTO: An - exactly. That was (INAUDIBLE).

WEST: --changed the language. It is a "humanitarian situation", not a "humanitarian crisis". And you do have a complicit media that's going along with it and that affects your ability to be able to make proper decisions to rectify the situation. But Neil, in closing, remember this - we have a President that went around the Congress and he enacted by executive order an immigration policy which has now caused this problem down on our southern border.

CAVUTO: Well, I just heard the back and forth and he was blaming the Republicans but for now, Millard Fillmore hasn't been blamed by I'm sure given time, Fillmore and his shenanigans will come to light.

Allen West, it's always good having you. Thank you very, very much.

By the way, political correctness still stands for the "calorically- challenged" instead of "fat". That one I'll let stay.

Meanwhile, did you hear about this Google executive - big, big tech executive, gets killed by a prostitute - we are told - allegedly. They met, connected on a social media site. The guy who heads that site, after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEP. CHIEF STEVE CLARK, SANTA CRUZ POLICE: So callous that in gathering her things, she was literally stepping over the body and at one point, stepped over the body to grab a glass of wine and finish the glass of wine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right. This is a murder that is now suddenly rocking the tech world. It's even on the mainstream papers.

To Fox Business reporter Jo Ling Kent on the details that are beginning to come out. What do we know about this?

JO LING KENT, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: Well, Neil, we do know that this was a liaison that had perhaps happened several times. Allegedly, the woman involved injected heroin into a 51-year-old Google executive's body. He died. And like you just heard there, she had an extra sip of wine before she left. She stepped over the body. She closed the shades, closed the yacht, and left.

CAVUTO: All right. Now, that's the charge. Now, Forrest Hayes is a big Google exec, his yacht, married, so all the complications with that. They meet on a social site - we're going to get into that in a second. Was there any - was there any signs prior that either she had a record or he had reason to be concerned?

KENT: Well, reports say that she's had about 200 differently liaisons and looking at him, according to the Santa Cruz police, this was an extended type of affair. Now, what's interesting here is she's been charged-

CAVUTO: You say "extended". Had they had met prior to this instance?

KENT: Repeated - yes, repeated contacts. And this is coming from evidence off of the cell phone of Mr. Hayes. And she's been charged with four different counts. But you should know it's manslaughter, administering and transporting and possessing heroin, excuse me, prostitution, and destroying evidence. So this is a very serious case.

CAVUTO: So the charges that she shot the heroin into him, that she would not have known in that case - if this is true - that it would have killed him--.

KENT: Santa Cruz police are saying that he was welcoming the drug usage. So the issue though, of course, is that she's possessing illegal drugs.

CAVUTO: Right. And injects it into someone else, allegedly. He dies, now it's manslaughter. Now, it's a mess.

KENT: Right. And what's really a mess is taking a look at it from the bird's eye view of Silicon Valley. I reached out to Google. They say they have no comment other than their hearts go out to the family of Mr. Hayes. But overall, looking at the case, there is a lot of excess and a lot of wealth involved in Silicon Valley. This individual - Mr. Hayes - has worked at Sun. He also worked at a couple of other major tech companies. So-

CAVUTO: But those guys always tend to get a fair rap in the press. I mean, well, for Wall Street - but that's a Wall Street guy. Those guys - you expect bad behavior. That's the way these things tend to be treated.

KENT: It's true that Silicon Valley has a very different reputation especially among the wealthy. They're known to be more modest. Looking at some of their boards - the bulletin boards regarding his obituary, a lot of people really looked up to him. They said he was one of the best bosses they've ever had. He worked on Google Glass. He was clearly an innovator, an executive at Google who set a very high standard according to those who say they worked with him. So this is - it's a very tragic case overall. Very messy.

CAVUTO: Yes. Very messy, in an industry we don't see a lot of, at least some established press.

Jo Ling, thank you for breaking that down for us.

In the meantime, the website they allegedly met on, SeekingArrangement.com founder and CEO Brandon Wade joins me right now on the phone.

Brandon, do you screen those who use your site?

BRANDON WADE, SEEKINGARRANGEMENT.COM CEO (ON THE PHONE): There is some screening that happens, obviously. We look at every single profile of members when they submit a profile to make sure that they don't violate against our policy. We look at the pictures that they upload. And of course we rely on members reporting each other so there's some sort of a community self-policing that goes on. And it's important to note that the alleged, I guess, the female - her profile had never received a single report on the site.

CAVUTO: Not on the site but there were reports prior. But are you saying it's not your site's responsibility then to start putting that up there as well, or what?

WADE: Well, what I'm - what I'm saying is there has been no reports. That means no other members have actually reported on her account or her profile as having done something wrong. And her profile certainly looks normal, just like any other dating profile out there.

CAVUTO: Are you doing anything differently now, Brandon? That if all this turns out and that this woman is (INAUDIBLE) manslaughter and did inject this guy with heroin and he dies, are you going to change anything, anything more of a screening process? Is this just a glaring, tragic exception, what?

WADE: As it is, we already have background check as an option on our website. I'll let you know, neither of them have--

CAVUTO: But should it be an option? In other words, should it be an option? If there's the risk of something like this happening, should that now be a requirement?

WADE: Well, that's a tough thing because even if you make it a requirement, people will still meet no matter what. They'll meet at the bar. They'll meet anywhere. What we tell people to do is just be careful. I mean, this is case of recreational drug use gone wrong. Don't use drugs. I mean, that's the moral of the story here.

CAVUTO: There's always a risk at this sort of thing, to your point. I remember the Craigslist murders where this sort of thing that was happening. So it must be, I guess, user beware. But for those who hook up on sites such as yours, do you issue warnings? Is there something you say upfront that "Be careful here. Know what you're getting into." What?

WADE: Absolutely. I mean, we tell people how to date safely. I mean, there's a whole bunch of stuff. And - but this is - this is a really weird situation too. They have actually been seeing each other for a while. They have had several meetings. This is not a one-off-type relationship.

CAVUTO: Are you worried though that through no fault of your own, Brandon, that people are going to hear about your site and say, "Oh, that was the one with the crazy hook-up in which the top executive died and it's just too messy and let me go to some other site"?

WADE: The funny thing you should ask that because yesterday, we had the record-breaking day in terms of the number of sign-ups. And today is looking (INAUDIBLE) yesterday.

CAVUTO: Really?

WADE: So I'm not really sure why. But every time there's a bad news, it seems to be good news for our website. It's really strange.

CAVUTO: In other words, it would be more guys than women, more women than guys, what?

WADE: Well, typically more women sign up than men. And of course, with this news going out there with - as breaking news, we are seeing way more men signing up in the last two days.

CAVUTO: Amazing. Brandon Wade. Thank you. Hope this all works out. It is sad. Hopefully, it's an exception, far from the rule. Brandon Wade.

All right. You probably heard this latest talk that Citigroup is close to settling a $7 billion fine with the United States government. In case you're counting, worth what - $30 billion in bank fines? I am far from a big supporter of banks and over that they are without sin. But is it me or do they keep coming up as the only sinner? Just weird. After this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Normally, we get a lot of comments over something I've said or discussed on this show or my Fox News show. But this concerns something I wrote for our Fox Business website about all these bank fines - the latest $7 billion likely slapped on Citigroup - likely double that for Bank of America for their respective parts in the meltdown you would think that only they had caused. So I started asking where is the punishment for the politicians - the ones who egged them on, pushing them to making more loans, turn home ownership from a goal to (INAUDIBLE) birthright.

Jane in Anthem, Arizona: "Neil, I worked in the mortgage industry during the fiasco. Your accountability was the absolute best description I've read. The real truth is what the banks were encouraged and sometimes forced to do by our government has not widely been published. Thanks for you for this honest account."

J.A. in Carson City: "Hey, you jerk! It's not just the banks that have paid a price for the - he said "damn", that's where I'm going to leave it - financial farce. My family will never recover from the lost value of our home. And the banks deserve to pay every dime of the punishment they get! Get your f*ing facts straight before you start preaching."

And J.A., banks are the only one responsible for what happened? No one else? Zero? Just them? Really? Who is the jerk, sir? Who is the one who has to get his facts straight before preaching?

Harry e-mails: "Thanks, Neil. First article I've read in a long time placing the blame for the 2007-2008 financial breakdown where it belongs."

"Some of your points like the Community Reinvestment Act are rarely mentioned anymore. Where do all the receipts the government has received in the form of penalties go? Does it go right back to the Treasury?"

Well, pretty much, Rick. It does. It all goes back into the same big old pot and around and around she goes.

All right. To our Fox Biz All-Stars, Monica Mehta, Jonathan Hoenig, and Mattie Duppler.

Jonathan, what do you make of this?

JONATHAN HOENIG, CAPITALISTPIG ASSET MANAGEMENT: Oh, Neil, there's been a con job perpetrated on the American public over the last five or six years. And this idea that Wall Street caused the collapse, it was greedy profit- seeking financiers and unregulated speculators that caused the collapse. In fact, Obama made a video saying just that. In reality, all elements of the financial system that failed were regulated and the ones that failed the most were regulated the most. To allude to your (INAUDIBLE) too many of them - the Community Reinvestment Act. So the free markets don't fail but we didn't have a free market and that's what exactly what caused it to fail and will continue to cause failures in the years to come.

CAVUTO: And I've been around long enough and I'm covering all of this that I can distinctly remember Congresses and Presidents of both parties saying, "You know you're not lending enough", that we've got a housing boom here potentially right beneath us, "Why don't you get with the program and start lending more? Loosen standards a little bit so we can get more people in on the fun." And this was the emergence of no doc loans where people with $50,000 incomes could buy million-dollar homes and better. They bear some responsibility. The politicians who egged this on bear some responsibility. Yet they're the ones who are handing out these punishments. Again, I am not saying that banks (INAUDIBLE) responsibility for securitizing a lot of the stuff, (INAUDIBLE), selling suspicious debt on maybe unbeknownst investors even though a lot of those investors knew exactly what they were buying. But I'm tired of the blame game and then only blaming them for it.

MATTIE DUPPLER, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM DIRECTOR: Right. And I mean, the question you're asking is an important one. Who's regulating the regulators? And the answer is no one or they're regulating themselves. I mean, a lot of these guys over at the Consumer Protection Bureau - they have had all of their - all of the regulations essentially taken off of them with the advent of Dodd-Frank and now they're just - they're acting as regulators gone wild because they don't have rules that govern them (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: By the way, they left Fannie and Freddie out of this because of their political kinships and friendship. So that's sort of like leaving Charles Manson out of the discussion of the Sharon Tate murders.

But my only other issue, Monica, is look, right after the meltdown, immediately, Congress said, "You lent too much. You were going crazy." A few months after the meltdown, they said, "Why aren't you lending? You're drying up lending." I tell you, these banks can't win for love or money.

MONICA MEHTA, SEVENTH CAPITAL MANAGING PRINCIPAL: Well, I think banks deserve the angst that they get. But to your point, which politicians are holding politicians accountable and which voters are holding politicians accountable? If you look at polls of how people feel about Congress--.

CAVUTO: I bet those politicians right now who are telling them "Open up the spigot. You're being too tight in your lending standards." The same standards that they advocated for right after the meltdown.

MEHTA: Right. And then we're talking about how there isn't enough talk--.

CAVUTO: I want to see their photos in post offices around the country.

MEHTA: And aspects of Dodd-Frank have made it much harder for small businesses to actually get lending. There's all sorts of hypocrisy in all sides of it.

CAVUTO: Because Washington's cures make the illness worse. That's where I come from (INAUDIBLE).

HOENIG: And Neil, you saw the same thing we mentioned with Dodd-Frank a few times. Think back what a decades with Sarbanes-Oxley. That was past reaction to the last big financial crisis. Remember Enron and Adelphia - that caused a lot of small companies not to be able to go public because of the expense it will raise some more. So every time we get a crisis caused by government, controls breed more controls. You get more control. I think that's why despite all the regulation that was supposed to fix the financial crisis - to Monica's point - we haven't seen the lending pick up. We also haven't seen the job creation and employment pick up that's directly due to these controls in the financial sector.

CAVUTO: Bottom line, we're all human beings and we all make our own bed and we all are realistic enough when we sign on a loan. But we signed it. Nope, no one coerces it. I have yet to run into a McDonald's and the manager force feeds me a double Quarter Pounder. I did it myself!

Meanwhile, when we come back, a federal judge today looking for answers on the IRS and all this targeting Conservatives. But did we just find the one smoking gun? Via an e-mail that we thought was missing? After this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right, but we warned you about this judge who is now looking into the whole e-mail mess and the targeting conservatives at the IRS, but did he just find a smoking gun? A former IRS director admitting in e-mail, no less, that she warned employees about what they write in the e-mails. Even asking a tech employ at the IRS which messages and emails are traceable. Back with the all-stars, Monica, Jonathan, and Maddie. Mattie, this is your smoking gun.

MATTIE DUPPLER, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM DIRECTOR: You would think so, right? You have someone warning her employees not to e-mail sensitive things in an e-mail. So that in and of itself demonstrates not only .

CAVUTO: That would be like me e-mailing my staff, could you kind of erase the e-mails like .

DUPPLER: Emails, right.

CAVUTO: They don't, they save them.

DUPPLER: So, I mean it's speculative just in the context of what she's saying but she also seemed to get it wrong. She was asking about whether or not the messages are available to Congress or they'll be deleted? That kind of thing. That shows that there was some kind of intent there, some kind of interest in keeping whatever it was she was IM'ing or e-mailing secret. So that raised the question right there. And the fact that we now have a judge who thinks that the American public deserves an answer for that, I think, is a very important step towards getting to the bottom of that.

CAVUTO: And this is the same judge who wanted the heads up on how did all these e-mails go disappearing and why didn't give us a heads-up earlier on how they all disappear. Practically wanting to subpoena the server they were on.

MONICA MEHTA, SEVENTH CAPITAL MANAGEMENT PRINCIPAL: Look, highly unusual, I mean you don't have emails disappear from six different computers for six different users.

CAVUTO: Certainly, not at the IRS.

MEHTA: It is not uncommon to be a corporate policy that you should watch what you e-mail. I mean back when e-mail was young in the 1990s you could .

CAVUTO: This is about hiding it.

MEHTA: Right, but so it's all in the context. But if it is just watch what you e-mail, like that is common communication policy.

DUPPLER: But if she's a manager, why does she have to inquire about this at this point? What, five, ten years into her career. Shouldn't you already know this if you are in charge?

CAVUTO: Because going on to say, John, - but when you start mentioning things in e-mail and discerning what are traceable messages and e-mails, that gets into the icky category.

JONATHAN HOENIG, CAPITALISTPIG ASSET MANAGEMENT: Well, if it's purposely deceptive, Neil. If that was in a corporation, it would be totally unacceptable and potentially criminal. This isn't even a corporation. Those aren't a company's computers, those are the people's computers. And Lois Lerner is in a high-level executive at Cisco or Microsoft. She's literally a gun. That's what the IRS is. It's government force brought to individuals finances. So in the most transparent administration in history, it's more than a little bit suspect that six hard drives with the smoking gun as you point out at it, potentially the smoking gun, suddenly go missing.

CAVUTO: Suddenly go missing, that's right. That just doesn't make sense, you know? Normally all e-mails should disappear when that happens.

DUPPLER: Right. Maybe we should be combining the NSA and the IRS, maybe that's what the solution is here. The president is trying to expand what the kind of bureaucracy we already have.

CAVUTO: If you are going to hide stuff, guys, you got to hide everything.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Just advise you. Criminal. Anyway, here's why the president is not going to the border.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: This isn't theater. This is a problem. I'm not interested in photo-ops.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: You're not interested in photo-ops? Then I'm not interested in ponderosa buffets.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Yeah, one of my next guests buying a car sight unseen. I'm going to go ahead and buy this car, without seeing, it I have a good idea what it's like, and I'm going to put in my order and hopefully they'll deliver to my house. Would you do that? Maybe if it's really new cars. Maybe some of you would. But you certainly want to kick the tires or certainly read up on the car you're about to buy. But the president is doing the equivalent of that sight unseen, not going to the border and then, at the same time arguing for $3.7 billion to address this border mess and the processing for this better than 50,000 largely kids who just made their way here. All right. So do those two connect? Leaving aside the fact that the president argue that he didn't want to go to the border because he's not into photo-ops, which, of course, he is. All right. We have auto dealer Mark Calisi here and real estate expert Katrina Campins. As the auto guy, Mark, how many customers of yours do that?

MARK CALISI, AUTO DEALER: Zero.

CAVUTO: right?

CALISI: Zero. Imagine you come into my dealership to buy a car and I'm saying you, Neil, give me a check for$50,000 first, then I'll let you look at the car, then I'll tell you about the options, but not until you give me a check for 50,000, and I deposit it.

CAVUTO: You would scare me. So I would do that. Just to get of the showroom. But I mean. No, it just - Right? It defies credulity?

CALISI: It's not. It's outrageous that he's asking for $3.7 billion from the American taxpayers to handle these illegal, and I say illegal immigration crisis without having any type of a plan. And just we went into a bank and wanted to borrow $10,000.

CAVUTO: Well, it was like you were dealing when the auto bailouts and everything else - in the effect. He didn't reason out the fallout for good dealers who are having good sales and being forced to shut down or relocate, whatever, without thinking it through.

CALISI: A lot of people got hurt, a lot of families got hurt and the taxpayers are going to get hurt. Now the dealers suing the federal government and the federal government is ready to stop paying the dealers back.

CAVUTO: So, there is nothing of GM and the separate lawsuits. You're right. But Katrina, what I wonder about is, how this looks now, the president not going to the border. That's just once and all - the whole thing that he doesn't like photo-ops was a little strange to me. But what damage is done here and how - wouldn't it hurt his cause to get that 3.7 billion?

KATRINA CAMPINS, REAL ESTATE EXPERT: Well, from my industry's perspective, which is real estate, nobody purchases a home without sight unseen. The same thing with .

CAVUTO: No, they did during the boom. They did during the boom. They were buying condos, sight unseen.

CAMPINS: Preconstruction.

CAVUTO: Right.

CAMPINS: But Neil, many of those people did come in to do the final walk through before they actually closed on the property. But those days are really no longer. Even in preconstruction projects right now, when people are seeing it sight unseen, they still are doing the walk through and they still are making sure that they feel the actual products, especially because there's more required down now. So, the days of only putting 5 percent down are over. As far as large - but in the luxury market, for instance, the $2 million, $3 million, $4 million homes. People want to see those homes.

CAVUTO: Yeah, what about the 3.7 billion dollar homes. How does that go? Well, a good point, guys. I mean I'm just saying that anything that costs a lot, I would like to check it out. And, you know, Mark, to your point, accountability means everything and accountability means visibility. It means seeing what you're getting into.

CALISI: I agree. Like I said to you before, I have never seen in all my years in business, someone just laying out a blank check and saying trust me.

(LAUGHTER)

CALISI: Don't go there.

CAVUTO: So you worry with this border issue is what? That we can't trust whatever deal we get or it's going to get more expensive or it's going to be a waste, what?

CALISI: Since there isn't a plan, one it is going to become more expensive. Right now the only thing we're doing is housing the women, men and children coming over the border right now. We do not have a plan to move forward. We have a plan with Mexico because -- and Canada as a continuous - as a border state. But why don't we have that same plan with Honduras and El Salvador and Guatemala? Why don't we have it with them? And just put them right back to where they were. No, we have that due process. The American taxpayers are paying for this. The 3.7 billion is a drop in the bucket compared to what it really - is going to be down the road.

CAVUTO: And Katrina, if I could belabor, you are one of the best real estate people I know. But I do know a thing or two when you look to buy a home, a lot of your types, those who are very good at this, they'll dress it up. They'll make sure it's an inviting home. Sometimes you put vanilla candles or something like that where it makes it alluring. So that when you go in there, you know, I might go ahead and invest in this or look around in this. There's been none of that done with this deal, and I think what scares me is, we haven't even tried to make it an inviting deal. We've just got ahead and say, there, there's the price, pay it or else?

CAMPINS: Well, I think a lot of people are concerned with this particular bill, because given Obama's history with other bills, there has been an influx of money, but then there hasn't been a plan of action. It costs the taxpayers and then there's no execution plan. So I think that's the major concern. And that's a lot of money to simply allocate to this particular bill. So, but you're right, Neil. And you know, things need to be staged, you need to feel it. You need to have a plan of action before you invest a large sum of money

CAVUTO: Absolutely. I know when my kids are selling houses, my wife said we are going to have to take down the Velvet Elvis, just for the sale. Just so, you know. All right. Mark, Katrina, thank you both very, very much. We want to hear their perspectives. Because they know a thing or two about how that would fly in their industries. It wouldn't. All right, coming up: What if I told you someone is making double your salary without even having the job? I bet they're working right around you, right now.

HOENIG: Tell me again about evil big business, you know, just exploiting, exploiting everybody. I mean companies are guilty regardless, right, if they don't pay their interns, they say they are exploiting, you know, underaged kids, if they do pay their interns, they are catching hell for that as well.

CAVUTO: You know, that's a very good point. That's a very good - Is there happy medium though, can we not be at 80,000 plus, but I do hear your point.

This is why everyone who wants to raise the minimum wage doesn't get it. It's not the wage that really matters. It's the skills, it's the work experience, it's the work ethic, taking responsibility that's the biggest payoff from any internship or low level ..

Apr 22, 2019( DownWithTyranny: http://downwithtyranny.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-pAR9msKemwA/XLy-Aw-j2fI/AAAAAAABkOk/xV5_Kfyc8CoktBVv0mZemydJNhKIgc-8QCLcBGAs/s1600/rkhanna0906.jpg Establishment Democrats have always hated Bernie. Most people are unaware that when Bernie first ran for Congress-- as an independent-- the Democratic Party ran establishment candidates against him. In his first congressional campaign (1988) the Democrats ran a conservative spoiler, Paul Poirier, state House majority leader, who allowed a Republican, Peter Smith win the seat: • Peter Smith (R)- 98,937 (41.2%) • Bernie (I)- 90,026 (37.5%) • Paul Poirier (D)- 43,330 (18.9%) Some in the Democratic Party didn't give a rat's ass; they opposed Bernie as vigorously as they opposed Smith, maybe more so. And in 1990, they ran an African-American woman, Dolores Sandoval, in the hope of pulling away votes from Bernie, whose popularity was surging. They knew she had no chance to win, but they preferred to see the Republican incumbent reelected than the independent SOCIALIST win. But the independent socialist did win... and by a lot: • Bernie (I)- 117,522 (56.0%) • Peter Smith (R)- 82,938 (39.5%) • Dolores Sandoval (D)- 6,315 (3.0%) Bernie entered Congress in January of 1991 and began caucusing with the Democrats. The Party didn't like his influence and the Democratic establishment wanted to get rid of him ASAP. He talked about how the Democrats and the Republicans represented the interests of wealthy donors, not the interests of working families. It hit a nerve with the Democrats because it was true and it was embarrassing for them. In 1991, he founded the Congressional Progressive Caucus which he hoped would offer progressives a way of distinguishing themselves from Democrats. (Brief tangent: The current co-chair, Mark Pocan, a more conventional liberal Democrat, must have lost sight of that when he started recruiting New Dems into the caucus, watering it down and wrecking its credibility.) In 1992, the Democrats ran Lewis Young in the hope of taking away enough votes from Bernie to allow the seat to flip back to the GOP. The disgusting strategy failed again-- and Bernie's popularity soared: • Bernie (I)- 162,724 (57.78%) • Tim Philbin (R)- 86,901 (30.86) • Lewis Young (D)- 22,279 (7.91%) Howard Dean, then Governor of Vermont, had had enough and persuaded the state Democratic Party to back Bernie. Nonetheless, four years later, the establishment Democrats were flipping out about "the Socialist" and tried the same tired trick, which once again, flopped: • Bernie (I)- 140,678 (55.2%) • Susan Sweetser (R)- 83,021 (32.5%) • Jack Long (D)- 23,830 (9.3%) That pretty much ended it-- although Democrat Larry Drown ran against Bernie in 2004, his last run for Congress-- and Bernie clobbered him and the Republican, taking 205,774 votes (67.5%). People in Vermont liked him, more than they liked either of the establishment political parties and their crappy candidates. Today, the wealthy donor class hates Bernie as much as they ever did-- whether the GOP wealthy donors or the Democratic Party wealthy donors. They know that when he says he's for change, it's real and profound change, not a few tweaks around the edges (Obama change). Last week, writing for the New Republic, Alex Shephard noted that Bernie's loudest opponents are party insiders who don't represent a political constituency of any significance[1]-- and their strategy is self-defeating. Bernie is the frontrunner "and entering the White House in January of 2021 both seem increasingly possible, maybe even probable... [Bernie's] most vocal opponents in the party are an assemblage of establishmentarians and familiar Beltway hands, none of whom speak for a political constituency of any size or significance. Moreover, far from hurting Sanders, this impotent assault is self-defeating, fueling the narrative that party gatekeepers want, at all costs, to keep a political revolution from taking over the Democratic Party." There is undoubtedly an ideological component of the anti-Sanders wing of the party that is often framed in practical terms. Attacks on Sanders (and other high-profile Democrats like Rep. Alexandria-Ocasio Cortez) often contend that left-wing goals like socialized medicine will be an electoral albatross, dooming the party to failure in battleground states. These arguments are rarely presented in policy terms, but it's easy to draw a line between an opposition to Sanders rooted in the Democratic Party's donor class and Sanders's high-tax proposals and class-war rhetoric.While there's a growing backlist of articles detailing the resistance within Democratic fundraising circles, most of the criticisms of Sanders center around the question of 'electability.' Media Matters founder David Brock told Politico last month that he believed that Sanders would struggle to unite the Democratic Party's many unruly factions and that his sizable war chest would make it easy for him to stay in the race, even if there were little chance he could win. Former Missouri Senator Claire McCaskill echoed this sentiment to the Times, saying, 'One thing we have now that we didn't in '16 is the uniting force of Trump. There will be tremendous pressure on Bernie and his followers to fall in line because of what Trump represents.'...There's another possible, if unintended, effect of the growing challenges to Sanders from Democratic establishment circles, however. Trump's best chance at victory doesn't come from a democratic socialist claiming the nomination, but from a third-party candidate splitting the vote. Claims from Democratic stalwarts that Sanders can't unseat the president are fool's gold to self-funding candidates like Howard Schultz, who argues that a majority of voters are clamoring for a centrist, corporate candidate. If anyone is splitting the party and undercutting Democrats' chances, if anyone is paving the way for a second Trump term, it isn't Sanders—it's his most obstinate and obstreperous opponents. Play Video[2]And that brings us right to Greg Jaffe's Washington Post piece from yesterday: Capitalism In Crisis: U.S. Billionaires Worry About The Survical Of The System That Made Them Rich[3]. "For decades," he wrote, "Democrats and Republicans have hailed America's business elite, especially in Silicon Valley, as the country's salvation. The government might be gridlocked, the electorate angry and divided, but America's innovators seemed to promise a relatively pain-free way out of the mess. Their companies produced an endless series of products that kept the U.S. economy churning and its gross domestic product climbing. Their philanthropic efforts were aimed at fixing some of the country's most vexing problems. Government's role was to stay out of the way. Now that consensus is shattering. For the first time in decades, capitalism's future is a subject of debate among presidential hopefuls and a source of growing angst for America's business elite. In places such as Silicon Valley, the slopes of Davos, Switzerland, and the halls of Harvard Business School, there is a sense that the kind of capitalism that once made America an economic envy is responsible for the growing inequality and anger that is tearing the country apart." Americans still loved technology, Khanna said, but too many of them felt locked out of the country's economic future and were looking for someone to blame."What happened to us?" he imagined people in these left-behind places asking.Part of Khanna's solution was to sign on as co-chairman of the presidential campaign of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT), the democratic socialist who rose to the national stage by railing against "the handful of billionaires" who "control the economic and political life of this nation," and who disproportionately live in Khanna's district.The other part of Khanna's solution was to do what he was doing now, talking to billionaire tech executives like Larsen who worried that the current path for both capitalism and Silicon Valley was unsustainable. Boosted by a cryptocurrency spike last year, Larsen's net worth had briefly hit $59 billion, making him the fifth-richest person in the world before the currency's value fell.Without an intervention, he worried that wealth would continue to pile up in Silicon Valley and anger in the country would continue to grow."It seems like every company in the world has to be here," Larsen said. "It's just painfully obvious that the blob is getting bigger."At some point, Larsen and Khanna worried, something was going to break.The 2008 financial crisis may have revealed the weaknesses of American capitalism. But it was Donald Trump's election and the pent-up anger it exposed that left America's billionaire class fearful for capitalism's future.Khanna was elected in 2016, just as the anxiety started to spread. In Europe, far-right nationalist parties were gaining ground. Closer to home, socialists and Trump-inspired nationalists were winning state and congressional elections.Conversations of the sort that Khanna was having with Larsen were now taking place in some of capitalism's most rarefied circles including Harvard Business School, where last fall Seth Klarman, a highly influential billionaire investor, delivered what he described as a "plaintive wail" to the business community to fix capitalism before it was too late. Play Video[4]The setting was the opening of Klarman Hall, a new $120 million conference center, built with his family's donation. "It's a choice to pay people as little as you can or work them as hard as you can," he told the audience gathered in the 1,000-seat auditorium. "It's a choice to maintain pleasant working conditions... or harsh ones; to offer good benefits or paltry ones." If business leaders didn't "ask hard questions about capitalism," he warned that they would be asked by "ideologues seeking to point fingers, assign blame and make reckless changes to the system."Six months after that speech, Klarman was struck by how quickly his dire prediction was coming to pass. Leading politicians, such as Trump, Sanders and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) were advocating positions on tariffs, wealth taxes and changes in corporate governance that would have been unthinkable a few years ago.Klarman wasn't opposed to more progressive taxation or regulation. But he worried that these new proposals went much too far. "I think we're in the middle of a revolution-- not a guns revolution-- but a revolution where people on both extremes want to blow it up, and good things don't happen to the vast majority of the population in a revolution," he said.He wasn't the only one who felt a sense of alarm. One of the most popular classes at Harvard Business School, home to the next generation of Fortune 500 executives, was a class on "reimagining capitalism." Seven years ago, the elective started with 28 students. Now there were nearly 300 taking it. During that period the students had grown increasingly cynical about corporations and the government, said Rebecca Henderson, the Harvard economist who teaches the course."What the trust surveys say is what I see," she said. "They are really worried about the direction in which the U.S. and the world is heading."A few dozen of those students spent their winter break reading Winners Take All, a book by Anand Giridharadas, a journalist and former McKinsey consultant, that had hit the bestseller list and was provoking heated arguments in places like Silicon Valley, Davos and Harvard Business School. Giridharadas' book was a withering attack on America's billionaire class and the notion that America's iconic capitalists could use their wealth and creativity to solve big social and economic problems that have eluded a plodding and divided government.This spring, Giridharadas took his argument to Klarman Hall. He slammed Mark Zuckerberg, taking aim at the Facebook founder's $100 million effort to fix Newark's faltering schools and his $3 billion push to end disease in a generation. "I'm glad he's trying to get rid of all the diseases, [but] I wish Facebook wasn't a plague," Giridharadas said.   https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-MFn3t-W0cRc/XLy-UZ0GS6I/AAAAAAABkOs/_1izrjacZaYTBAJ2OnOnOcq-vW9OTZ89gCLcBGAs/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2019-01-29%2Bat%2B4.26.32%2BPM.pngHe trashed Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz's independent presidential run as an effort to protect the interests of the uber-wealthy. And he lambasted the notion, frequently championed by the likes of Bill Gates and Barack Obama, that Silicon Valley's innovations would disrupt old hierarchies and spread capitalism's rewards. "Really?" Giridharadas asked. "Now five companies control America, instead of 100! And a lot of those companies are whiter and more male than the ones they disrupted."For many of the students, schooled in the notion that business could make a profit while making the world a better place, Giridharadas' ideas were both energizing and disorienting. Erika Uyterhoeven, a second-year student, recalled one of her fellow classmates turning to her when Giridharadas was finished."So, what should we do?" her colleague asked. "Is he saying we shouldn't go into banking or consulting?"Added another student: "There was a palpable sense of personal desperation."Khanna experienced a version of this desperation almost every day in his district. He grew up in an overwhelmingly white, middle-class suburb of Philadelphia. After college and Yale Law School, he moved to Silicon Valley in 2003, hoping to use his training as a lawyer to help set the rules for a lawless online world.In 2014, backed by the tech community and a long roster of billionaire donors, Khanna challenged an eight-term incumbent in a Democratic primary and lost. The defeat caused him to reflect on what he had missed-- in particular, the problems that runaway capitalism were causing in his district, where the median home value in formerly blue-collar cities surged past $2 million."The best thing that happened to me was that I lost my 2014 election," he said. "Had I won... maybe I would've been a traditional neoliberal. It really forced my self-reflection and it pointed out every weakness I ever had."In California, Khanna's home is a small apartment around the corner from a Dollar Tree, one of only two in his district. His wife and two children live most of the year in Washington, where home values are cheaper.His days are split between meetings with billionaires and his many constituents who are struggling to stay afloat amid Silicon Valley's success. "I am an 11-year renter with a master's degree," a teacher told him at a meeting with school employees. Her question wasn't about whether she would ever be able to afford a home, but about a fellow teacher who couldn't afford health insurance.A few days earlier, he had met with two activists who wanted his help pressuring big tech companies to pay contract janitorial and cafeteria workers a living wage. Khanna agreed to host a press event on their behalf.The billionaires in Khanna's district, meanwhile, were consumed by a different worry. Mixed in with the valley's usual frothy optimism about disruption and inventing the future was a growing sense that the tech economy had somehow broken capitalism. The digital revolution had allowed tech entrepreneurs to build massive global companies without the big job-producing factories or large workforces of the industrial era. The result was more and more wealth concentrated in fewer hands.As technology advanced, some feared things were only going to get worse. Robots were eliminating much factory work; online commerce was decimating retail; and self-driving cars were on the verge of phasing out truck drivers. The next step was computers that could learn and think."What happens if you can actually automate all human intellectual labor?" said Greg Brockman, chairman of OpenAI, a company backed by several Silicon Valley billionaires. Such thinking computers might be able to diagnose diseases better than doctors by drawing on superhuman amounts of clinical research, said Brockman, 30. They could displace a large number of office jobs. Eventually, he said, the job shortages would force the government to pay people to pursue their passions or simply live. Only Andrew Yang, a long-shot presidential candidate and tech entrepreneur, supported the idea of government paying citizens a regular income. But the idea of a "universal basic income" was discussed regularly in the valley.The prospect was both energizing and terrifying. OpenAI had recently added an ethicist-- Brockman sometimes referred to her as a "philosopher"-- to its staff of about 100 employees to help sort through the implications of its innovations. To Brockman, a future without work seemed just as likely as one without meat, a possibility that many in the valley viewed as a near certainty. "Once we have meat substitutes as good as the real thing, my expectation is that we're going to look back at eating meat as this terrible, immoral thing," he said. The same could be true of work in a future in an era of advanced artificial intelligence. "We'll look back and say, 'Wow, that was so crazy and almost immoral that people were forced to go and labor in order to be able to survive,'" he said.Khanna heard such prophecies all the time but mostly discounted them as sci-fi fantasy. His focus was on fixing the version of capitalism that existed today. He often pleaded with big tech executives to spend just 10 percent of their time thinking about what they could do for their country and 90 percent to their companies.The tougher question was exactly what he wanted them to do with that 10 percent.On a warm spring evening, Khanna was trying to answer that question for about two dozen Silicon Valley tech executives, software engineers and venture capitalists. The group gathered at a $5 million Mediterranean-style villa perched atop a hill overlooking Cupertino, which glittered in the valley below.Khanna described a December trip he organized to tiny Jefferson, Iowa, for a group of tech executives that included Microsoft's chief technology officer and a LinkedIn co-founder. The executives donated to the community college's scholarship fund and paid to equip its computer lab with the goal of training 25 to 35 students for software developer jobs, starting at $65,000 a year.Khanna had made similar trips to West Virginia, Ohio and Kentucky. The total number of jobs these trips produced was small, and the pay wasn't great. Still, Khanna believed they served a larger purpose. They proved that people in Silicon Valley cared about places like Jefferson, a rural town of only 4,200. They gave people hope that even the remotest parts of America could take part in the country's tech revolution.The next step, Khanna told the executives at the mansion in Cupertino, California, was a $100 million effort to build 50 technology institutes, similar to land-grant colleges, to train workers in left-behind parts of America. Khanna had already introduced a bill that he admitted was unlikely to pass. But that wasn't really the point. "It sets a blueprint," he said.   https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Tige7YYGHeA/XLy-rJ-Oj4I/AAAAAAABkO0/-Lfwq_YYrxsfSaVpdllnefLiTXd-gyBGQCLcBGAs/s1600/RepRoKhanna.pngKhanna's blueprint reflected his broader view of how to unite an increasingly polarized country. Many Democrats blamed Trump's victory and the country's divisions on racial tensions as the nation grew more diverse and whites lost their favored positions.Khanna had a different view. He saw the country's problems primarily as the product of growing income inequality and a lack of opportunity.Sometimes Khanna imagined what people in these left-behind parts of the country were thinking: Their grandparents had fought in World War II and helped build the country's industrial age economy. Now they worried people like Khanna, whose parents emigrated from India, were surging past them."They just got here, and they are doing really, really well," Khanna imagined these people saying. "What happened to us?"...A few days after the meeting at the Cupertino mansion, Khanna was standing in front of 16,000 amped-up Sanders supporters. The San Francisco skyline rose in front of him and the Golden Gate Bridge spanned the bay behind him.In his gray suit and pressed white shirt, the two-term congressman looked a bit out of place-- an emissary from establishment Washington crashing someone else's revolution. Khanna gave a brief speech introducing Sanders, who a few minutes later rushed onto the stage and into the same campaign spiel he had been delivering since the 2016 Democratic primaries.He bashed the billionaire class and its influence over American elections. "Democracy means one person one vote and not billionaires buying elections," Sanders yelled in his Brooklyn growl."We say no to oligarchy," he continued. "Yes to democracy."Khanna's eyes fixed on Steve Spinner, a big tech investor in Silicon Valley and major fundraiser for Obama's 2008 and 2012 presidential campaigns. Spinner, who chaired Khanna's congressional win, was listening with his arms folded across his fleece vest."We dragged him out here," Khanna said. "He's about as far from Bernie as you can get."Many of Khanna's billionaire supporters-- even those who worried about capitalism and inequality-- seemed genuinely puzzled by Khanna's affection for Sanders.For Khanna it was simple: In Sanders, Khanna found a candidate who shared his diagnosis of the country's most vexing problems: inequality and the failures of unrestrained capitalism.Sanders wasn't a perfect match for Khanna. Sanders didn't really understand the tech industry-- though he wasn't calling for the breakup of big tech companies like Warren and some other candidates. Warren's proposal, if executed, would hurt companies in Khanna's district and alienate some of his wealthiest backers.Khanna wished Sanders would talk more about the greatness of the American economy and the power of the tech industry, when properly taxed and regulated, to lift people out of poverty. But on that score Khanna believed he could help Sanders."We can quibble over his plans to solve this issue or that issue," Khanna said. "But I have no doubt that if Bernie Sanders was in the White House, he'd wake up every day thinking, 'How do I solve structural inequality in America?'"The 77-year-old socialist's speech had passed the one-hour mark and the crowd was still laughing, cheering, hooting and shouting."We're probably not going to get a lot of support from the one percent and the large profitable corporations," Sanders said.A voice in the crowd screamed an expletive."That's OK," Sanders continued, "I don't need, and we don't want, their support."The congressman in the gray suit gazed out at the crowd, which stretched to the back of the park. Khanna saw Sanders' revolution as an imperfect solution to a near-impossible problem. For now, though, it was the best he could find. In past discussions on the same topic, I always got the idea that Khanna felt that Bernie would bring a moral urgency-- and system-defying zeal-- to issues of income inequality and unrestrained capitalism, which motivate both of them politically. It looks to me that Khanna, as one of the most prominent of Bernie's surrogates, used his interview or interviews with Jaffe to frame Bernie's policies in terms of far brighter American future, not just for the true-believers but for people who haven't been persuaded yet. If anything, it's this kind of perceptive reporting by Jaffe that will help expand Bernie's base. Let's hope so!Play Video[5] [ 1]:   https://newrepublic.com/article/153605/impotence-stop-sanders-democrats [ 2]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/k5tCYg9s0HU [ 3]:   https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/capitalism-in-crisis-us-billionaires-worry-about-the-survival-of-the-system-that-made-them-rich/2019/04/20/3e06ef90-5ed8-11e9-bfad-36a7eb36cb60_story.html [ 4]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/_9CNEedZBxc [ 5]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/nVYFQl54rXU

urn:contentItem:5X3S-0MX1-F021-611S-00000-00Regina Doherty faces further DPC criticism of public services card2019-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:26ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Regina Doherty faces further DPC criticism of public services cardMark Tighe

Regina Doherty's department faces two more negative findings from the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner (DPC) as part of investigations into the public services card.

Last week the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection published the DPC's report, which found it was illegal for the government to insist people use the card to access non-welfare services.

The government has rejected the findings and is set to appeal against them in court. The office is expected to issue an enforcement notice by the end of this month - Doherty has said the department will appeal against this.

The DPC is carrying out two further investigations into the department. Sources say both are likely to lead to more negative findings.

One is the second module of the public services card inquiry that is examining the data kept by the department in relation to the card, including whether officials are processing biometric data on each cardholder. Biometrics refers to an individual's body measurements.

The department says each card contains a photograph, but insists that no biometric data is stored. It uses facial-matching software and a database to check for fraudulent duplicate claimants and says this is kept to its "own secure data centres".

Separately, the department is under investigation over allegations that it interfered with the independence of its own data protection officer, when it changed an official online data declaration to remove a reference to processing biometric data. The office has issued the department with a draft report indicating that it believes there was a breach of data protection rules through the interference with its data protection officer. The commissioner is considering the department's response.

Some data protection officials in Europe are concerned that the DPC's high-profile actions against the Irish government may distract the regulator from investigations into Facebook and Google.

Graham Doyle, the DPC's head of communications, said the commission was experienced at running multiple investigations and had dedicated teams working on the big-tech investigations and public sector cases.

"We have grown significantly since 2014, when we had about 30 staff compared with the 140 today," said Doyle. "However, this expansion must continue to ensure we can continue to regulate effectively."

urn:contentItem:5TR0-BR81-JDG9-Y1G5-00000-00Regional challenges, technology and trust are focus of new publication from the Ethical Journalism Network2019-04-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:26ZLexisNexisRegional challenges, technology and trust are focus of new publication from the Ethical Journalism Network

Washington, DC: International Center for Journalists has issued the following press release:

Each year, the Ethical Journalism Network (EJN) publishes a magazine where they look broadly at pressing topics and challenges for journalism around the world. This year’s publication, released at the International Journalism Conference in Perugia in early April, takes a sobering tone with the title, “Saving the news: Ethics and the fight for the future of journalism.”

The topics are diverse, ranging from an in-depth look into journalists’ challenges in South Sudan to the ethics of photographic manipulation. Two themes, however, stand out in both the articles and the coverage surrounding the publication’s release: technology and trust — both of which place the publication’s topics squarely in the heart of conversations taking place in all corners of the journalism world today.

“There's a first world crisis in terms of information, and that can be characterized as a major crisis of trust with the audience,” EJN president and founder Aidan White told IJNet.

“People are confused by the chaos of the internet, about not knowing on what they can rely or what they can't rely,” White, who also contributed to the publication, continued. “[The] result is that people are, on the one hand, refusing to believe anything they read in the media, and on the other hand, believing everything they read in the media.”

In the publication’s foreword, the Principal of Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford and chair of the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism, Alan Rusbridger, discusses the rise and fall of tech giants like Facebook, as well as their destructive impact on the news industry. He argues, however, that finger-pointing is as much a distraction as it is a reality.

Rusbridger also notes two places where he considers journalists to have failed in building trust — covering both Brexit and climate change.

“Set aside the politics and ask, what message do we want a sceptical public to believe about journalism?” he writes. “Is it primarily a craft of verification or opinion? Is it there to give a factual basis for debates society needs to have, or is it there to push the beliefs of an individual proprietor or editor?”

The issue of public skepticism surrounding the media sets the backdrop for many of this year’s articles. Still, the title itself offers more hope than is immediately visible. Rather than being bogged down by challenges, the articles instead serve as both a plea and a roadmap for more solutions.

While White does not hesitate to sound the alarm about both journalism and, consequently, democracy, he says we’re on the verge of a “golden age” in journalism.

“We are so caught up with the sense of crisis, that we are not aware of it,” he says.

Frustrated by the nostalgia for a journalism that he says he has never seen, White argues that there was never actually a time when journalism was free from issues of trust. Now, however, his optimism stems from the potential he sees in new technologies that likely will transform the ways in which news is created and distributed.

“We have opportunities to provide [the] public interesting information on scale and with the level of efficiency, and with the level of accuracy and relevance, which is unheard of,” says White.

In the publication, White’s own articles first focus on the role of ethics in the face of danger and authoritarianism, and later, on a case for further regulation of Big Tech.

Other topics covered in this year’s magazine include hate speech, safety, solutions-focused journalism, governance and more. In total, the articles span the spectrum of topics and geographies — from Honduras, the Philippines, Spain, Kosovo and more.

“As always, we wanted an authentic voice from the regions... [people] that understand the situation to talk really about what's going on,” White explained.

Looking ahead, White is excited not just about journalism’s potential, but also about the work of EJN. Just last month, for instance, the organization named a new director, Hannah Storm, who kicked off her work by introducing the publication at a panel in Perugia.

“I think what's she's going to bring to it is a real, fresh energy and some new issues as well. We haven't done enough on issues related to gender, for example,” says White. “We're going to work more on security issues as well. And Hannah's a really inspiring person to have around in the leadership team, so I think it all looks really good for the future.”

The tools competition authorities can use to restore fair competition Document date: 2019-02-08 P8_QE(2019)000408 Questions for written answer

Brussels: Public Register European Parliament has issued the following document:

1175217.EN PE 633.462 Question for written answer E-000408/2019 to the Commission Rule 130 Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE) Subject: Competition, data and the market power of digital platforms - is data an essential facility? The tools competition authorities can use to restore fair competition At a citizens’ dialogue in Dublin1, 2, 3, Commissioner Vestager said that the ‘debate on whether Google search is an essential facility hasn’t concluded yet’, adding: ‘the most urgent debate is about access to data’4. Some big tech platform argue that people don’t really care about privacy as they click all the cookies and pop-ups without reading the details because they want to stay online and continue using the App. However, Europe’s data protection regulators have received more than 95 000 complaints5 about possible data breaches, eight months after the adoption of a landmark EU privacy law. This demonstrates that EU consumers do care about how their data6 is being used and passed to third parties and data brokers7. 1. Does DG Competition agree that personal data is an ‘essential facility’8, in the sense that it is essential for competitors or prospective competitors unable to emerge because a few companies have a monopoly on owning and keeping the data? 2. Can the EU competition authority confirm that structural separation or unbundling is one of the possible tools available to it to restore fair competition under normal market conditions9? 3. Can the Commission confirm that it can re-open and reassess the Facebook-WhatsApp merger if new details are brought to its attention or it has previously been supplied with misleading or incorrect information? 1 https://ec.europa.eu/ireland/events/european-commission-representation-ireland-events-citizens-dialogue-eucompetition_ en 2   https://ec.europa.eu/commission/commissioners/2014- 2019/calendar_en?field_editorial_section_multiple_tid=189 3   https://www.facebook.com/EUIreland 4   https://twitter.com/simonvandorpe/status/1088740632150134784 5   http://news.trust.org/item/20190125112939-5m5xw/ 6   http://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/E-8-2019-000001_EN.html 7   http://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/E-8-2019-000054_EN.html 8   https://www.concurrences.com/en/glossary-of-competition-terms/Essential-facility 9 See my previous Written Question in relation to Android Apps,   http://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/E-8-2019-000001_EN.html

Brussels: Public Register European Parliament has issued the following document: ECON committee DIRECTORATE GENERAL FOR INTERNAL POLICIES POLICY DEPARTMENT A: ECONOMIC AND SCIENTIFIC POLICY Competition issues in the Area of Financial Technology (FinTech) STUDY Abstract The increasing number of FinTech services provided by newcomer start-ups, traditional financial institutions and big tech companies can bring new competition challenges to the playing field. Some factors can result in anticompetitive behaviours, namely the network effects derived from the use of online platforms, the access to customer data, standardisation, interoperability and the use of algorithms. Combined with a service-by-service analysis, the study provides both, descriptive analysis and normative tools to anticipate and manage anticompetitive behaviours as they occur. This document was provided by Policy Department A at the request of the ECON Committee.

Brussels: Public Register European Parliament has issued the following document:

 

ECON committee

DIRECTORATE GENERAL FOR INTERNAL POLICIES POLICY DEPARTMENT A: ECONOMIC AND SCIENTIFIC POLICY Competition issues in the Area of Financial Technology (FinTech) STUDY Abstract The increasing number of FinTech services provided by newcomer start-ups, traditional financial institutions and big tech companies can bring new competition challenges to the playing field. Some factors can result in anticompetitive behaviours, namely the network effects derived from the use of online platforms, the access to customer data, standardisation, interoperability and the use of algorithms. Combined with a service-by-service analysis, the study provides both, descriptive analysis and normative tools to anticipate and manage anticompetitive behaviours as they occur. This document was provided by Policy Department A at the request of the ECON Committee. 1189117.EN PE 640.539Question for written answer E-002887/2019to the CommissionRule 138Carmen Avram (S&D)Subject: Digital technologies and antitrust cases: competition tools and regulations, from finesthrough structural remedies to changing the status quoParliament’s resolution of 27 November 20141 on supporting consumer rights in the digital singlemarket was adopted by a vast majority of the House. It stated: ‘calls, furthermore, on the Commissionto consider proposals aimed at unbundling search engines from other commercial services as onepotential long-term means of achieving the aforementioned aims’.In the USA, attitudes toward big tech companies seem to be changing2, as outlined by 48 StateAttorneys General in the Google Antitrust Investigation3. In the Federal Trade Commission4 thedissenting statement of FTC Commissioner Rohit Chopra confirms some past criticisms: ‘theCommission repeats many of the same mistakes from the flawed Facebook settlement: no individualaccountability, insufficient remedies to address the company’s financial incentives, and a fine that stillallows the company to profit from its lawbreaking.
